{
 "cells": [
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 1,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "import numpy as np\n",
    "import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n",
    "import seaborn as sns\n",
    "plt.style.use('seaborn')"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 2,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "# constants\n",
    "π = np.pi"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "# Introduction\n",
    "\n",
    "This notebook will introduce some high-level ideas in machine learning through the lens of the example of polynomial curve fitting. We will see:\n",
    "\n",
    "- Machine learning models are trained on \"training data\" and can be evaluated on unseen \"test data\"\n",
    "- Fitting data to a polynomial curve amounts to solving a linear system\n",
    "- Models can be fit too well to the training data (overfitting) don't do well on other data\n",
    "- We can help alleviate overfitting with a process called \"regularization\"\n",
    "- We can attempt to quantify model uncertainty in machine learning models by incorporating Bayesian ideas\n",
    "\n",
    "## Polynomial curve fitting"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "Take a training set comprising $N$ observations at $x= (x_1,\\ldots,x_n)$ with observed values $t=(t_1,\\ldots,t_n)$. In many real data sets, there is an underlying regularity to be learned, but individual observations are corrupted by noise. This might be due to true stochasticity introduced by random processes, or there could be sources of variability which are unobserved.\n",
    "\n",
    "\n",
    "The goal is for a new input $\\widehat{x}$, to predict the target variable $\\widehat{t}$.  We use a simple curve fitting model with the function $y\\colon \\mathbf{R}^{}\\times \\mathbf{R}^{m+1}\\to \\mathbf{R}^{}$\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation}\n",
    "y(x,w) = w_0 + w_1 x + \\ldots w_M x^M = \\sum_{i=0}^{M} w_i x^i\n",
    "\\end{equation}\n",
    "\n",
    "This is called a \"linear model\" because although $y(x,w)$ is nonlinear in $x$, it is linear in $w$."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 3,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "f = lambda x: np.sin(2*π*x)\n",
    "xx = np.linspace(0,1,100)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 4,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "N = 10\n",
    "σ = 0.3\n",
    "\n",
    "x = np.linspace(0,1,N)\n",
    "ϵ = σ * np.random.randn(N)\n",
    "t = f(x) + ϵ"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 5,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 432x288 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {
      "needs_background": "light"
     },
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "plt.plot(xx, f(xx), label=r'$f$')\n",
    "plt.scatter(x, t, label=r'observations')\n",
    "plt.legend();plt.show()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "We will determine $w$ by minimizing an error function that measures the misfit between the training set and the function $y(x,w)$. A simple choice for error functions is the sum of squared errors.\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation}\n",
    "E(w) = \\frac{1}{2} \\sum_{n=1}^{N} \\left(y(x_n, w) - t_n\\right)^2\n",
    "\\end{equation}\n",
    "\n",
    "We want to minimize this error function over the available training data."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Solving the minimization problem\n",
    "\n",
    "We seek $w$ such that $\\nabla_w E(w) = 0$. Each component of the gradient should vanish.\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{align}\n",
    "\\frac{\\partial }{\\partial w_i}E(w) \n",
    "&= \n",
    "\\frac{\\partial }{\\partial w_i} \\frac{1}{2}\\sum_{n=1}^{N} \\left(y(x_n,w) - t_n\\right)^2 \\\\\n",
    "&= \\sum_{n=1}^{N} \\left(y(x_n,w) -t_n\\right) \\frac{\\partial }{\\partial w_i}(y(x_n,w) - t_n)\\\\ \n",
    "&= \\sum_{n=1}^{N} \\left(y(x_n,w) -t_n\\right)x_n^i\n",
    "\\end{align}\n",
    "\n",
    "since\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation}\n",
    "\\frac{\\partial }{\\partial w_i}(y(x_n,w) - t_n)\n",
    "=\\frac{\\partial }{\\partial w_i}(w_0 + \\ldots + w_M x^M - t_n) \n",
    "= x^i\n",
    "\\end{equation}\n",
    "\n",
    "The condition that the $i^{th}$ component vanishes is\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation}\n",
    "\\sum_{n=1}^{N} w_0 x_n^i + \\ldots w_Mx_n^{i+M} - t_n x_n^i = 0\n",
    "\\end{equation}\n",
    "\n",
    "which can be written as the linear system $Aw = b$ where \n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation}\n",
    "A_{ij} = \\sum_{n=1}^{N} x_n^{i+j}, \\qquad b_i = \\sum_{n=1}^{N} t_n x^i.\n",
    "\\end{equation}\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "The function below computes weights for a given training set and polynomial order."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 6,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "def polyfit_weights(x, t, M):\n",
    "    # increment M to account for 1x1 matrix at p=0\n",
    "    N, M = len(x), M+1\n",
    "    A, b = np.zeros((M, M)), np.zeros(M)\n",
    "    for i in range(M):\n",
    "        for j in range(M):\n",
    "            A[i,j] = np.sum(x**(i+j))\n",
    "            b[i] = np.sum(t*(x**i))\n",
    "    w = np.linalg.solve(A, b)\n",
    "    return w"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 7,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "y = lambda x, w: np.polyval(np.flip(w), x)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 8,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 576x504 with 4 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {
      "needs_background": "light"
     },
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "fig, axes = plt.subplots(2,2,figsize=(8,7))\n",
    "for ax, M in zip(axes.reshape(-1), [0, 1, 3, 9]):\n",
    "    w = polyfit_weights(x, t, M)\n",
    "    ax.plot(xx, f(xx))\n",
    "    ax.scatter(x, t)\n",
    "    ax.plot(xx, y(xx, w), label=r\"$M={}$\".format(M)); \n",
    "    ax.set_ylim(-1.1,1.1); ax.legend()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Model selection and overfitting\n",
    "\n",
    "Increasing the model order to $M=9$ results in no training error and the polynomial passes through every training point. However, as a result, the function oscillates wildly and poorly represents the underlying data. This behavior is called *overfitting*.\n",
    "\n",
    "To better assess generalization, we can segment all data into a training dataset and a test dataset and select a model that generalizes well to the test data.\n",
    "\n",
    "The root mean squared (RMS) error is defined as\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation}\n",
    "E_{\\text{RMS}} = \\sqrt{2 E(w)/N}\n",
    "\\end{equation}\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 9,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "def generate_dataset(N, σ=0.3):\n",
    "    x = np.linspace(0,1,N)\n",
    "    ϵ = σ * np.random.randn(N)\n",
    "    t = f(x) + ϵ\n",
    "    return x, t"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 10,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "y_xw = lambda x, w: np.polyval(np.flip(w), x)\n",
    "E = lambda y, w, x, t: 0.5*np.sum((y(x,w) - t)**2)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 11,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "E_RMS = lambda E,N: np.sqrt(2*E/N)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 12,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "# training data\n",
    "N_train = 10\n",
    "x_train, t_train = generate_dataset(N_train)\n",
    "\n",
    "# testing data\n",
    "N_test = 20\n",
    "x_test = np.random.rand(N_test)\n",
    "ϵ = σ * np.random.randn(N_test)\n",
    "t_test = f(x_test) + ϵ"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 13,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "RMS_errs = {'test':[], 'train':[]}\n",
    "ws = []\n",
    "for m in range(10):\n",
    "    w = polyfit_weights(x_train, t_train, m)  \n",
    "    fitted = lambda x, w: np.polyval(np.flip(w), x)\n",
    "    training_error = E(fitted, w, x_train, t_train)\n",
    "    test_error = E(fitted, w, x_test, t_test)\n",
    "    RMS_errs['train'].append(E_RMS(training_error, N_train))\n",
    "    RMS_errs['test'].append(E_RMS(test_error, N_test))\n",
    "    ws.append(w)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 14,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 432x288 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {
      "needs_background": "light"
     },
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "plt.plot(np.arange(10), RMS_errs['train'], '-o', label='train')\n",
    "plt.plot(np.arange(10), RMS_errs['test'], '-o', label='test')\n",
    "plt.title(r'RMS error vs model order $M$')\n",
    "plt.legend();plt.show()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "There are diminishing returns past an order $M=3$ and bad overfitting at $M=9$."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 24,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 432x288 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {
      "needs_background": "light"
     },
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "for m in range(10):\n",
    "    w = ws[m]\n",
    "    plt.scatter(x=np.ones_like(w)*m, y=np.abs(w), c='gray')\n",
    "plt.title(r'absolute coefficient values $|w|$ vs $M$');\n",
    "plt.semilogy(); plt.show()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "A numerical interpretation is that the coefficients are growing very large in order to exactly fit the training set at $M=9$."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Regularization"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "To stop the coefficients from growing too large, *regularization* adds a penalty term to the error function. One choice is the modified error function\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation}\n",
    "\\tilde{E}(w) = \\frac{1}{2} \\sum_{n=1}^{N} \\left(y(x_n, w) - t_n\\right)^2 +\n",
    "\\frac{\\lambda}{2} \\left\\Vert w\\right\\Vert_{2}^{2} \n",
    "\\label{eq:ridge_reg}\n",
    "\\end{equation}\n",
    "\n",
    "The parameter $\\lambda$ determines the relative importance of the regularization term and the sum-of-squares error term. The coefficient $w_0$ is often ommitted from regularization because it represents an offset which corresponds to choice of origin. The regularization choice in (\\ref{eq:ridge_reg}) is called *ridge regression*.\n",
    "\n",
    "\n",
    "Using our previous result, we can modify our condition that the gradient with respect to the weights vanishes.\n",
    "\n",
    "since \n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation}\n",
    "\\frac{\\partial }{\\partial w_i} \\frac{\\lambda}{2} \\left\\lVert w\\right\\rVert_2^2 \n",
    "=  \\frac{\\lambda}{2} \\frac{\\partial }{\\partial w_i} \\sum_{i=1}^{M} w_i^2 \n",
    "= \\lambda w_i,\n",
    "\\end{equation}\n",
    "\n",
    "The modified gradient is \n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation}\n",
    "\\frac{\\partial \\tilde{E}}{\\partial w_i} \n",
    "= \\sum_{n=1}^{N} \\left(y(x_n, w) - t_n\\right) x_n^i \n",
    "+\\lambda w_i\n",
    "\\end{equation}\n",
    "\n",
    "From which it is straightforward to work out that the only modification to the linear system is the addition of a $\\lambda$ term to the diagonal."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 16,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": [
    "def regularized_polyfit_weights(x, t, M, λ):\n",
    "    # increment M to account for 1x1 matrix at p=0\n",
    "    N, M = len(x), M+1\n",
    "    A, b = np.zeros((M, M)), np.zeros(M)\n",
    "    for i in range(M):\n",
    "        for j in range(M):\n",
    "            A[i,j] = np.sum(x**(i+j))\n",
    "            b[i] = np.sum(t*(x**i))\n",
    "        A[i,i] += λ\n",
    "    w = np.linalg.solve(A, b)\n",
    "    return w"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 17,
   "metadata": {
    "scrolled": true
   },
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 576x288 with 2 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {
      "needs_background": "light"
     },
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "# training data\n",
    "M = 9\n",
    "N_train = 10\n",
    "x_train, t_train = generate_dataset(N_train)\n",
    "\n",
    "# compute regularized and unregularized weights\n",
    "w_unreg = polyfit_weights(x_train, t_train, M)\n",
    "w_reg = regularized_polyfit_weights(x_train, t_train, M, λ=np.exp(-17))\n",
    "\n",
    "# plot\n",
    "fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,2,figsize=(8,4))\n",
    "for axis in ax:\n",
    "    axis.plot(xx, f(xx))\n",
    "    axis.scatter(x_train, t_train)\n",
    "ax[0].plot(xx, y(xx, w_unreg))\n",
    "ax[0].set_ylim(-1.1,1.1); ax[0].set_title('no regularization')\n",
    "ax[1].plot(xx, y(xx, w_reg)); ax[1].set_title(r'$\\ln\\,\\lambda = -17$')\n",
    "plt.show()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "## Probabilistic viewpoints"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "If we assume that, given an input value $x_0$, the target value will be normally distributed around the predicted value $y(x_0,w)$, then the probability of making an observation $t_0$ is described by a Gaussian probability density function with mean $y(x_0,w)$ and variance $\\sigma^2$ (which we assume is known).\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation*}\n",
    "P(t_0|x_0, w, \\sigma^2) = \\mathcal{N}\\left(t \\mid y(x_0,w), \\beta^{-1}\\right),\n",
    "\\end{equation*}\n",
    "\n",
    "where we have written the distribution in terms of the precision $\\beta \\equiv 1/\\sigma^2$. Observations are presumed to be independent, so the likelihood of the set of target observations $t$ given the inputs $x$ is \n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation*}\n",
    "P(t|x,w,\\beta) = \\prod_{n=1}^N \\frac{1}{(2\\pi\\sigma^2)^{1/2}} \\exp\\left(-\\frac{1}{2\\sigma^2} (y(x_n,w) - t_n)^2\\right)\n",
    "\\end{equation*}\n",
    "\n",
    "From a prediction point of view, we seek the $w$ which maximizes the likelihood given the inputs $x$. This is equivalent to maximizing the log-likelihood, which we can write as \n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{align*}\n",
    "\\log P(t|x,w,\\beta) &= \\log \\prod_{n=1}^N \\frac{1}{(2\\pi\\sigma^2)^{1/2}} \\exp\\left(-\\frac{1}{2\\sigma^2} (y(x_n,w) - t_n)^2\\right)\\\\\n",
    "&= \\sum_{n=1}^N \\log\\frac{1}{(2\\pi)^{1/2}} + \\log \\left(\\frac{1}{\\sigma^2}\\right)^{1/2}  +  \\left(-\\frac{1}{2\\sigma^2} (y(x_n,w) - t_n)^2\\right)\\\\\n",
    "&= -\\frac{N}{2} \\log(2\\pi) + \\frac{N}{2} \\log\\beta - \\sum_{n=1}^{N} \\frac{\\beta}{2} \\left(y(x_n,w) - t_n\\right)^2\n",
    "\\end{align*}\n",
    "\n",
    "The first two terms in the log-likelihood don't depend on $w$ and can be dropped, since they don't affect the optimal value. Finally, instead of maximizing the log-likelihood, we can minimize the negative log-likelihood, which amounts to solving the equivalent unconstrained optimization problem\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{align*}\n",
    "\\text{minimize}  \\; &  f_0(w) = \\sum_{n=1}^{N}  \\left(y(x_n,w) - t_n\\right)^2     &     \\\\\n",
    "\\end{align*}\n",
    "\n",
    "Thus minimizing the sum-of-squares error function is equivalent to the maximum likelihood estimate of $w$ under the assumption of Gaussian noise.\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Unknown error variance"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "We previously supposed the variance $\\sigma^2$ of the error distribution between predicted value $y(x_0,w$ and target value $t_0$ was known, but often, the variance is not known. In this case, we can find a maximum likelihood estimate of $\\beta$ as well by treating it as an unknown and maximizing the log-likelihood with respect to $\\beta$\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{align*}\n",
    "\\text{maximize}  \\; & f_0(\\beta) = \\frac{N}{2} \\log\\beta - \\sum_{n=1}^{N} \\frac{\\beta}{2} \\left(y(x_n,w) - t_n\\right)^2    &     \\\\\n",
    "\\end{align*}\n",
    "\n",
    "by taking the partial derivative with respect to $\\beta$,\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation*}\n",
    "\\frac{\\partial f_0}{\\partial \\beta} = \\frac{N}{2\\beta} - \\frac{1}{2} \\sum_{n=1}^{N} \\left(y(x_n,w) - t_n\\right)^2 = 0\n",
    "\\end{equation*}\n",
    "\n",
    "yielding the maximum-likelihood estimate for the variance\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation*}\n",
    "\\sigma^2_{\\text{MLE}} =  \\frac{1}{\\beta_{\\text{MLE}}} = \\frac{1}{N} \\sum_{n=1}^{N} \\left(y(x_n,w) - t_n\\right)^2.\n",
    "\\end{equation*}\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "We can use the error in the regularization example above to estimate the variance."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 18,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "text/plain": [
       "(0.14881932780263604, 0.3)"
      ]
     },
     "execution_count": 18,
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "execute_result"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "σ2_MLE = 1/N_train * np.sum( (y(x_train, w_reg) - t_train)**2 )\n",
    "σ_MLE = np.sqrt(σ2_MLE)\n",
    "σ_MLE, σ"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 21,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "\n",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 576x216 with 2 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {
      "needs_background": "light"
     },
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "# plot\n",
    "xx =np.linspace(0,1,200)\n",
    "yxw = y(xx, w_reg)\n",
    "fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,2,figsize=(8,3))\n",
    "for axis in ax:\n",
    "    axis.plot(xx, f(xx))\n",
    "    axis.scatter(x_train, t_train)\n",
    "    axis.plot(xx, yxw);\n",
    "ax[0].fill_between(xx, yxw-σ_MLE, yxw+σ_MLE,alpha=0.3, color='gray')\n",
    "ax[1].fill_between(xx, yxw-σ, yxw+σ, alpha=0.3, color='gray')\n",
    "ax[0].set_title(r'$\\sigma_{MLE}$'); ax[1].set_title(r'$\\sigma$')\n",
    "plt.show()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "We see that the esimate of the variance is smaller than the actual variance. That's because we chose a large enough variance in generating the data such that the curve fitting is \"fit\" better to the data than the actual underlying function, since we chose to minimize the sum-of-squares error to generate the weights in the first place!\n",
    "\n",
    "This would improve with additional training data."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "### Bayesian curve fitting"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "In the previous section, we made point estimates of $w$ as well as $\\beta$. A step towards Bayesian treatment would be to introduce a prior distribution over the weights $w$.\n",
    "\n",
    "**Introducing a prior distribution over** $w$\n",
    "\n",
    "We introduce a prior over the weights $w$. For simplicity, we choose a multivariate Gaussian prior on the weights with zero mean and precision $\\alpha$ and covariance matrix $\\Sigma = \\alpha^{-1}I$.\n",
    "We assume that the precisions $\\alpha$ and $\\beta$ are known.\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{align*}\n",
    "P(w|\\alpha) &= \\mathcal{N}\\left(w|0, \\alpha^{-1}I\\right) \\\\\n",
    "&= \\frac{1}{(2\\pi)^{(M+1)/2}|\\alpha^{-1}I|} \\exp\\left(-\\frac{1}{2}(w-0)^T\\,\\Sigma^{-1}(w-0)\\right) \\\\\n",
    "&= \\left(\\frac{\\alpha}{2\\pi} \\right)^{\\frac{M+1}{2}} \\exp\\left(-\\frac{\\alpha}{2} w^T w\\right)\n",
    "\\end{align*}\n",
    "\n",
    "where we have used\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation*}\n",
    "|\\alpha^{-1}I|^{-1} = \\left(\\alpha^{-1}\\right)^{-(M+1)/2} = \\alpha^{(M+1)/2}.\n",
    "\\end{equation*}\n",
    "\n",
    "The posterior distribution over $w$ is \n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation*}\n",
    "P(w|x,t,\\alpha, \\beta) \\propto P(t|x, w,\\beta) P(w|\\alpha)\n",
    "\\end{equation*}\n",
    "\n",
    "with log-likelihood\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{align*}\n",
    "\\log P(w|x,t,\\alpha,\\beta) &\\propto \\log P(t|x, w,\\beta) +  \\log P(w|\\alpha) \\\\\n",
    "&= - \\frac{\\beta}{2} \\sum_{n=1}^{N} \\left(y(x_n,w) - t_n\\right)^2\n",
    "+ \\frac{N}{2} \\log \\beta \n",
    "- \\frac{N}{2} \\log(2\\pi) \\\\\n",
    "&\\qquad + \\left(\\frac{M+1}{2}\\right) \\log \\left(\\frac{\\alpha}{2\\pi} \\right)\n",
    "- \\frac{\\alpha}{2} w^T w\n",
    "\\end{align*}\n",
    "\n",
    "For the purposes of maximizing the log-likelihood with respect to the weights $w$, we need only consider terms which depend on $w$, yielding the equivalent minimization problem\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{align}\n",
    "\\text{minimize}  \\; & f_0(x) = \\frac{1}{2} \\sum_{n=1}^{N} \\left(y(x_n, w) - t_n\\right)^{2} + \\frac{\\lambda}{2} \\left\\Vert w\\right\\Vert_{}^{2}  \n",
    "\\end{align}\n",
    "\n",
    "Maximizing the likelihood of the posterior distribution is equivalent to the minimization problem associated with regularized least squares with regularization parameter $\\lambda=\\alpha/\\beta$.\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "**Fully Bayesian treatment**\n",
    "\n",
    "Although in the previous section we introduced a prior on $w$, we are still making a point estimate of $w$. For a fully Bayesian treatment, we should integrate over all values of $w$. We will cover this in much more detail later; for now, we provide only a sketch of the idea and the final result.\n",
    "\n",
    "Our inputs are the training data set $(x,t)_{n=1}^N$ and given a new point $x^*$, we would like to find a predictive distribution for $t^*$, $P(t^*|x^*,x,t)$. Applying the factorization rules for $w$\n",
    "\n",
    "\\begin{equation*}\n",
    "P(t^*|x^*,x,t) = \\int P(t^*|x^*, w) P(w|x,t)\\, dw\n",
    "\\end{equation*}\n"
   ]
  },
